Award.AwardTitle: The 8th Annual CMU Electricity Conference: Data-Driven Energy Systems: From Data Collection to Information Technology for Sustainable Services

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project supports a workshop entitled `` DATA-DRIVEN ENERGY SYSTEMS: From Data Collection to Information Technology for Sustainable Services?? to be held at Carnegie Mellon University on March 12-14, 2012. It is a part of the 8th Carnegie Mellon University Electricity Conference that provides a venue for structured brainstorming by the thought leaders in multiple communities. One of the key premises in this workshop is that IT-enabled flexible utilization of assets is key to sustainable energy services. However, the challenge is enormous as the industry paradigm shifts from the predictive, worst-case centralized data management to highly distributed interactive data and resource management. Invited talks by the academic, industry and government participants will be presented to pose these problems more formally, to assess state-of-the-art, and to investigate new approaches. The conference proceedings will provide a point of reference for future research and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported a workshop concerning ``Data-Driven Sustainable Energy Systems”. The March 12-14, 2013 workshop was co?organized by Marija Ilic from Carnegie Mellon University and Richard Schuler from Cornell University. The workshop was the main part of the 8th CMU Electricity Conference; its record can be found in http://www.ece.cmu.edu/~electricityconference/2012/. One of the key objectives was to bring together leading researchers from across key disciplines, such as electric power systems, computer science and economic public policy, all working toward defining rapidly emerging use of data in physical infrastructures such as energy systems.

Intellectual Merit: One of the major messages to take out of the workshop was that it is not sufficient to design the best optimization tools without understanding the structure of dynamic processes (temporal spatial, contextual) in the domain application such as energy systems. This, in turn, requires taking a step back and revisiting currently used models and encouraging R&D efforts needed to enhance models for the evolving architectures. In short, one of the major workshop conclusions was that we are dealing with very complex network systems and that there are at present no well?established and accepted modeling, monitoring, communications nor decision making frameworks which are necessary to transform today’s grid into an enabler of sustainable energy services.

 

On the other hand, several academic views were presented concerning possible frameworks. It was clear from many presentations at the workshop that specific modeling and decision?making methods are proposed and that progress is being made, but there is major void regarding end?to?end valuation of these methods within the complex electric energy system. Another way of raising this issue is to think about the challenge of posing the use of many data?driven recent technologies, referred to a smart grid technologies (such as ``smart meters”, synchrophasors, storage, power electronically?controlled delivery equipment –Flexible AC Transmission Systems?, just to name a few discussed in the Workshop) need to be deployed and utilized with clear understanding of the customers’ needs. Otherwise, it was pointed out by several industry leaders, even the best technologies will not make it without subsidies. We are already beginning to witness bankruptcy of several lead technologies, solar and storage, in particular. This is, mainly, because at present there are no clear mechanisms to differentiate these technologies from base?load energy power plants. Data?driven methods are needed to implement and value flexibility.

 

Another, related, relevant conclusion from this workshop is that no single entity, stakeholder, has full information about the complex electric energy system, and, therefore, it becomes necessary to have multi?directional exchange of information between the (groups of) system users?system layers?. All layers can make decisions using their own data gathering, processing and assuming/learning through interactions the important effects of the rest of the system on the outcomes in the distributed layers.
